raw_text:
Survey confirms property slowdown
 
 Government figures have confirmed a widely reported slowdown of the UK's housing market in late 2004.
 
 House prices were 11.8% higher on the year in the last quarter of 2004, down from 16.3% in the July-to-September quarter, the Land Registry said. The average house price in England and Wales was £182,920, down from £187,971 in July-September. The volume of sales between October and December dropped by nearly a quarter from the same period in 2003. The government figures are the first official confirmation of falls in the market at the end of 2004. Land Registry figures are less up to date than those of banks and building societies, since they record completions not mortgage approvals. However, the figures are viewed as the most accurate measure of house prices as they include all property transactions, including cash sales.
 
 The cost of buying a home fell in seven out of 10 regions between the third and fourth quarters of 2004.
 
 The biggest annual gains were made in Wales, where house prices were up by 23% in the fourth quarter. House prices rose the slowest in Greater London, being up by 6%. In the capital, the volume of sales fell by 23% from 36,185 in 2003 to 28,041 for the same period in 2004. There was also a decline in the number of million-pound properties sold in the capital, with 436 properties over £1m sold compared to 469 for the same period in 2003. Although the figures point to a slowdown in the market, the most recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax have indicated the market may be undergoing a revival. After registering falls at the back end of 2004, Halifax said house prices rose by 0.8% in January and Nationwide reported a rise of 0.4% in the first month of the year. Members of the Bank of England's rate-setting committee will make their latest decision on interest rates on Thursday.
llama3.2:1b: House prices in the UK were higher in the fourth quarter of 2004 than in July-September, down from 16.3% growth to 11.8%. The average house price was £182,920, down from £187,971 in July-September. House prices fell in seven out of ten regions, with Wales seeing a 23% increase and Greater London's decline being the slowest at 6%.
llama3.2:3b: UK housing market slowdown confirmed by Land Registry figures, with house prices 11.8% higher year-on-year, down from 16.3%. Average price in England and Wales fell to £182,920, while sales volume dropped by nearly a quarter in the last quarter of 2004. The cost of buying a home fell in seven out of 10 regions, with the biggest gains in Wales (23%) and slowest in Greater London (6%).
gemma2:2b: UK housing market slowdown confirmed: House price growth slowed from July-September, prices down, sales volume declined.  Cost of buying homes fell in 7 out of 10 regions. Wales saw largest annual gains (23%), while London saw slowest growth (6%). Sales and million-pound properties sold declined in the capital. Recent surveys suggest market revival may be underway.  Bank of England interest rate decision coming Thursday.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Survey confirms slowdown in UK housing market. House prices fell 16.3% to £187,971 in July-September 2004. Volume sales dropped by nearly a quarter compared to the previous year. Average house price in England and Wales was £182,920, down from £187,971 in July-September. Nationwide and Halifax reported increases in January and February 2005, suggesting a market recovery. The government figures from Land Registry are less up-to-date than those of banks and building societies.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Government figures confirm a UK housing market slowdown in late 2004, with house prices down from 16.3% to 11.8%. Average English and Welsh house prices dropped to £182,920 from £187,971. Sales volume fell by nearly 25% compared to 2003. Wales saw the largest price increase at 23%, while London experienced the lowest growth of 6%, with a decrease in sales and luxury property transactions. Despite recent market fluctuations, some reports suggest possible recovery.
qwen2.5:3b: Government figures confirm UK housing market slowdown with average house price at £182,920 (down from £187,971 in July-September). House prices rose by 6% in Greater London compared to 23% in Wales. Sales volume dropped nearly a quarter and the cost of buying homes fell in seven out of ten regions between the third and fourth quarters of 2004. Despite these declines, recent surveys suggest market revival; Halifax reported a January rise of 0.8% and Nationwide a 0.4% increase. The Bank of England's interest rate decision is upcoming.
opencoder:1.5b: The Government figures have confirmed a slowdown in the UK's housing market, specifically in the late 2004 period. The house prices rose from £16,300 to £18,800 during the last quarter of 2004, down from £17,400 in July-to-September. The average house price has dropped by approximately 11%. The volume of sales between October and December has gone down nearly a quarter compared to 2003. The figures are considered the most accurate measure of house prices as they include all property transactions, including cash sales. The cost of buying a home has fallen among seven out of ten regions in 2004.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is:

Survey confirms property slowdown

Government figures have confirmed a widely reported slowdown of the UK's housing market in late 2004. House prices were 11.8% higher on the year in the last quarter of 2004, down from 16.3% in the July-September quarter, the Land Registry said. The average house price in England and Wales was £187,971, down from £187,971 in July-September 2003. The volume of sales between October and December dropped by nearly a quarter from the same period in 2003. The government figures are the most accurate measure of house prices as they include all property transactions, including cash sales.

The cost of buying a home fell in seven out of 10 regions between the third and fourth quarters of 2004.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about property prices in the UK between late 2004. Let me read through it carefully.

The main points are that the housing market experienced a slowdown at the end of 2004. House prices increased by 11.8% in the last quarter, down from 16.3% in July-September. The average price was £182k, which dropped to £187k. Sales volume also fell nearly a quarter.

Another key point is that land registry data is more recent and accurate since they track completions, not mortgage approvals. They saw seven out of ten regions' house prices fall in the third to fourth quarters.

Wales had the biggest gains with 23% increase in Q4. London had the smallest gain at 6%. There was a decline in sold properties above £1m, particularly in London, from 469 down to 436. Both Nationwide and Halifax's surveys suggested the market might recover.

So, I'll highlight these points: the slowdown ending, pricing trends across regions, volume changes, regional specifics like Wales and London, and upcoming data about the economy.
</think>

House prices in the UK fell sharply at the end of 2004, with an average increase of 11.8% to £182k compared to a decrease of 16.3% during the Q7-9 period. The volume of property sales dropped nearly a quarter from 2003 levels. Land registry data is more recent and accurate, as they track property completions rather than mortgage approvals. In Wales, house prices rose by 23% in the fourth quarter, while London had only a 6% increase. There was a drop in sold properties above £1m in London, from 469 to 436 units. The Bank of England's interest rate decision is expected soon. Nationwide and Halifax surveys suggested the market may recover.
tinyllama:1.1b: According to official figures from the Land Registry, the UK housing market slowed down significantly in late 2004 and experienced a drop in house prices by nearly 12%. This was confirmed in the government's latest survey of property transactions as well as the most recent reports from banks and building societies. The biggest gains in prices were seen in Wales, where buyers received higher returns on their properties, while the number of million-pound properties sold also declined. Despite these changes, the Land Registry figures suggest that the market is undergoing a revival following years of decline, with Halifax reporting a rise in house prices and Nationwide indicating a slowdown at the back end of 2004.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The survey confirms that property slowed down in late 2004, according to figures from the Land Registry and government figures. House prices were reported to be 11.8% higher on the year, down from a 16.3% increase in July-to-September quarter. The volume of sales dropped by almost a quarter compared to the same period in 2003. Land Registry records completions not mortgage approvals, but bank and building society figures include all property transactions, including cash sales. In seven out of 10 regions between third and fourth quarters of 2004, house prices decreased while the biggest annual gains were made in Wales. House prices rose by 23% in the fourth quarter, but fell at the back end of the year. As the Bank of England's rate-setting committee makes their decision on interest rates on Thursday, market observers are watching closely for any indication of a slowdown.
phi:2.7b: The UK housing market slowed down at the end of 2004, with house prices increasing by 11.8% compared to the same period the previous year, down from 16.3%. The average house price was £182,920 in England and Wales and the volume of sales fell by almost a quarter. There were also regional differences, with the biggest gains in Wales and the slowest growth in Greater London. However, recent surveys suggest that the market may be recovering, with Halifax reporting a rise of 0.8% and Nationwide indicating a rise of 0.4%. The Bank of England's rate-setting committee will make their latest decision on Thursday.
orca-mini:3b: The UK housing market slowdown was confirmed by government figures, with house prices dropping by 11.8% and the volume of sales dropping by nearly a quarter in the last quarter of 2004. Seven out of 10 regions saw gains in house prices, with the biggest gains being made in Wales, where prices rose by 23%. However, prices fell in Greater London, being up by 6%, and there was also a decline in million-pound property sales in the capital. The market may be experiencing a revival after falling at the end of 2004, with surveys indicating a rise in house prices in January and February.
hermes3:3b: Housing market slowdown confirmed; UK house prices 11.8% higher in Q4 2004 compared to previous quarter, but down from earlier levels.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: A survey confirmed a UK housing market slowdown in late 2004, with house prices 11.8% higher than the previous year and an average price of £182,920. Sales volume dropped by nearly 25% compared to 2003. The cost of buying a home fell in seven out of ten regions between Q3 and Q4 2004. Land Registry figures, viewed as most accurate, showed falls in the market, but recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax indicated potential revival. After registering falls at the end of 2004, Halifax reported house prices rose by 0.8% in January 2005, while Nationwide reported a rise of 0.4%.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Government figures confirm a slowdown in the UK housing market in late 2004. House prices rose 11.8% annually in the last quarter, down from 16.3% in the previous quarter, with the average price falling to £182,920. Sales volume dropped nearly 25% compared to 2003. Prices declined in seven out of ten regions, with Wales seeing the highest annual increase (23%) and Greater London the lowest (6%). London also saw a 23% drop in sales and fewer million-pound property transactions. Despite the slowdown, recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax suggest a potential market revival, with slight price increases in early 2005. The Bank of England's rate-setting committee is set to decide on interest rates soon.
stablelm2:1.6b: Government data confirms UK housing market slowdown, with house prices down 8% YoY in last quarter but still at £X,*X in England and Wales. Sales dropped nearly a quarter from Q3 to Q4, though recent surveys suggest possible market revival after October-December falls. Seven out of ten regions saw property price declines between Q3 and Q4, with Wales seeing the biggest increases. Interest rate decision by Bank of England members on Thursday will depend on these data points.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Government data confirms a property market slowdown in late 2004, with house prices in England and Wales decreasing by 11.8% year-on-year from July-September, to £182,920 per average. The volume of sales dropped by nearly a quarter from the same period in 2003. This is the first official confirmation of market slowdowns in late 2004. House price increases were greatest in Wales (23%), while Greater London saw the least growth (6%). In London, sales volume fell by 23%, and fewer high-value properties (£1m+) changed hands. Despite these trends, recent surveys from Nationwide and Halifax suggest a potential market revival, with house prices rising in January. The Bank of England's interest rate decision is imminent.
reference: House prices were 11.8% higher on the year in the last quarter of 2004, down from 16.3% in the July-to-September quarter, the Land Registry said.The biggest annual gains were made in Wales, where house prices were up by 23% in the fourth quarter.After registering falls at the back end of 2004, Halifax said house prices rose by 0.8% in January and Nationwide reported a rise of 0.4% in the first month of the year.However, the figures are viewed as the most accurate measure of house prices as they include all property transactions, including cash sales.The average house price in England and Wales was £182,920, down from £187,971 in July-September.House prices rose the slowest in Greater London, being up by 6%.
